comments:
Driver:  0427I

After running may be about 10 Web services scenarios and having created 8 J2EE 
Web modules, doing anything to the workbench is very slow.  Memory usuage gets 
to 146M and CPU usuage stays at 100% for a long time.  

If I bring down the workbench and starts again, I'm OK for 1 or 2 scenarios and 
will then run into this situation again.

I've tried again with the 0428I 19:21 driver and had similar problems.
This time all I did was to create 5 J2EE Web module, target them to Tomcat 5.0 
and tried starting the server.

When I tried to start the server, CPU usuage stays at 99% for a couple of 
minutes (it usually takes less than 30 seconds) and then I get the 
error "Server Tomcat v5.0 Server @ localhost failed to start" (it's probaby 
hitting a timeout).

The CPU time stays at 99% even after I get the error about server failing to 
start.  The workbench stays being unresponsive.

If I bring downn the workbench, reopen it and tried starting the server again, 
it was a bit better the first time but the problem shows up again if you stop 
and start again.

Now that I can consistently reproduce it, I think the problem is serious enough 
to be raised as a critical defect (it might even be a blocker).

I see j2ee and server tools in the stack trace when I do a Ctrl-break, so I'll 
start by assigning to jst.j2ee.  Please take a look and reassign if appropriate.

I'll also attach the workspace to this defect.

When I hit Ctrl-Break, this is the trace I got:

Hi, I reproduced this problem by creating a 5 J2EE modules, created a Tomcat 
v5.0 server, added all modules to the server and tried to start the server.

Hope this helps rather than adds confusion. The first observation is 
interesting, and the second stackdump is very similar to Kathy's.  Also, I 
noticed a noticeable degradation in processing power following the failure.

I first added ALL the modules, and noticed one was missing from the tree of 
modules under the server.  When I checked the "Add and remove projects..." 
dialog, it showed ALL the modules.  So, I removed all, and added it again, this 
time it worked.

After I sych with the following plugins that was fixed, I don't get the problem 
anymore:

- jst.j2ee
- jst.j2ee.ejb
- jst.j2ee.web
- wst.common.modulecore
- wst.server.core
- wst.server.ui

I was able to run the original scenario with 5 modules.  I also tried adding 6 
more modules to the server, starting and stopping the server is still fine.  So 
it looks like the problem had been fixed.  Thanks for the quick response!

The problem was caused by massive disk access as the Server searched for
modules. We updated some of the server module framework classes to be a little
smarter about checking for new modules or the removal of old modules. This fixed
part one of the problem. 

We also found that originally, the server table view would sometimes drop or not
show all modules that had been added to it. Using the new (only slightly
modified approach), we have overcome this problem as well. 

The second part of the problem was with the animation tag. We updated the
ServerTableViewer to use update() on the root elements, instead of a full
refresh(). update(rootElements) will only update the labels, not the full
structural tree. refresh() was causing alot of hits to the content provider, and
thus re-fetching all of the modules again. With update() it allows the
animation, without updating the modules in the tree. 

The changes to server were discussed with Tim deBoer, and updates to jst and
server were released. These are relatively small code changes, and of course all
non-breaking.
Changed Version field given new release numbering.
